thread.title: NYRA touts a good Saratoga season
thread.title_full: NYRA touts a good Saratoga season - Times Union

author: Rick Karlin
title: NYRA touts a good Saratoga season
text:
New York
The New York Racing Association's Reorganization Board of Directors touted Wednesday what they described as a successful season at Saratoga Race Course, which saw a NYRA record handle of $656,121,664 — a 14.1 percent increase over 2014 and well in excess of the previous record of $590,187,876 set in 2012.
NYRA officials also said there was a record on-track handle of $157,647,599, or a 4.8 percent increase over 2014. That too, surpassed the 2012 record of $150,637,998.
Chris Kay , the board's CEO and president, noted that they recorded a 13.8 percent increase in revenue from dining, concessions and merchandising, which was in keeping with a strong attendance of 1,065,625.
"Over the past two years, our efforts to enhance the overall experience and improve the quality of racing are clearly resonating with our horseplayers, our fans and with their families," Kay said.
The oversight board, put in place three years ago by Gov. Andrew Cuomo , has been criticized by some local Saratoga boosters who say it's time to put NYRA back in private hands, as opposed to a state-controlled oversight board.
The good financial performance of this past meet in Saratoga could be viewed as a sign, though, that the oversight board is doing a good job.
There is no firm timetable for when the oversight board will end.
Interest in Saratoga was heightened when American Pharoah became a Triple Crown winner at NYRA's Belmont stakes.
American Pharoah also raced in the Travers Stakes, where attendance was capped at 50,000. The Triple Crown winner ended up losing to Keen Ice. But American Pharoah's appearance sparked increased publicity and interest in the meet.
NYRA also raised restaurant seating prices and initiated a program in which visitors could pay to reserve picnic tables near the paddock.
Kay told board members at Wednesday's meeting that the Saratoga course saw physical improvements such as those at the Saratoga Walk of Fame, an open-air pavilion honoring owners, trainers and jockeys who have influenced the sport.
